awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Scale-Up of An Innovative Spray Pyrolysis Process for Producing Pyrochlore Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to commercialize Pyrochem Catalyst Company's (PCC) catalyst materials.   These catalyst materials are unique in that the catalytically active metal is atomically dispersed in a rigid crystalline matrix.  This imparts unparalleled thermal stability, even at temperatures in excess of 1000°C.  Conventional catalysts typically require much higher precious metal loadings (as much as 20 times) to achieve the same activity as the materials developed in this project and at high temperatures those active metals can agglomerate into large clusters reducing their performance and the lifetime of the catalyst.  The series of catalysts developed in this project are designed in a way that all precious metal is optimally utilized and protected.  This includes resistance from sulfur poisoning and the accumulation of carbon when operating under severe conditions.  This makes these materials ideal for high temperature processes such as steam methane reforming for hydrogen generation, autothermal reforming for syngas production, syngas generation in oxygen transport membranes (OTM), and exhaust oxidation in automotive catalytic convertors.     

The objectives of this Phase II STTR program are to build on the success of the Phase I objectives that developed a low cost and continuous catalyst manufacturing method for producing the pyrochlore powders that are the basis for the proposed catalyst product.  The method may be equally effective for producing other types of mixed metal oxides like perovskites and fluorites. In Phase II, PCC will construct and test a scaled-up production platform, following the design elements of the proof of concept demonstrated in Phase I.  The new unit will be designed to manufacture proprietary pyrochlore powders at a rate with a hundred-fold increase over production rates of the Phase I unit.  The Phase II technical efforts also examine a range of catalyst synthesis parameters like oxidant gas concentration/composition, temperature distribution in the production unit, precursor residence times, synthesis solution chemistry, and optimizing heat and mass transport.  Through a subaward, powders produced from the process will be characterized and tested for activity by the National Energy Technology Labs, Morgantown, WV.  The overall goal of this project is the development of a high throughput / high yield manufacturing process that produces high performance catalysts for commercial sale.

por.por_cntn:
Crystalline pyrochlore-based oxides have proven to be effective catalysts for the reforming and oxidation of hydrocarbons.  They display high chemical and thermal stability under demanding conditions: high temperature, feed impurities and environments that cause metal agglomeration (sintering) in conventional heterogeneous catalysts.  The pyrochlore structure is especially accommodating to the substitution of a wide variety of different metals, which enables the catalytic activity to be tailored for many different feedstocks, reactions and operating conditions.  In particular, the substitution of a catalytically active metal (Ni, Rh, Pt, Pd, Ru) into the pyrochlore structure makes the catalyst fundamentally different compared to traditional supported metals catalysts by creating structured near neighbor effects, crystal defects and the atomic distribution of the catalytically active metals.

Until now, the synthesis of these crystalline mixed-metal oxides required long and labor intensive batch scale procedures that made them economically non-competitive with conventional materials.  With the discovery and validation of a small-scale spray pyrolysis process (SPP) in a Phase 1 STTR, Pyrochem Catalyst Company focused on the scale-up of the SPP to the preparation of kilogram quantities of a broad range of pyrochlore catalysts covering applications ranging from steam methane reforming (SMR) to three-way automotive exhaust catalysts.

Intellectual Merit

Built around the concepts of rapid heat transfer to small droplets created from a high frequency or pneumatic spray nozzle, the SPP offers a low cost manufacturing approach to the continuous production of mixed metal oxide powders using water-soluble precursors.  In terms of their catalytic activity for hydrocarbon oxidation and steam reforming, the powders produced in our scaled up Phase IIB SPP reactor, in many instances, have performance that exceeds conventional catalysts of the same or similar composition. 

Our Phase IIB objectives were directed at scale-up of the SPP process from lab proof of concept (Phas e I & II) to a pilot unit that represents the penultimate step to a commercial process.  Today our small pilot unit has an average daily catalyst production rate of 5 kg/day

Specific applications within the Phase IIB program focused on production and testing of automotive exhaust emission catalysts because the high oxygen exchange capacity of pyrochlores is a critical components in catalytic convertors.

Broader/Commercial Impact.

Mixed metal oxide (MMO) catalysts are a mainstay of the chemical and refining industries.  They are used in a wide range of catalyzed reactions: oxidations, isomerization, alkylation, cracking, etc.   Crystalline mixed metal oxides can accommodate substitution of a wide range of different metals that enables their catalytic activity to be tailored to different types of reactions and feedstocks.   With the ability to control the catalytic properties through the selection and structural configuration of metal cations, introduction of nearest neighbor effects, dispersion of the catalytic metals at an atomic level and high thermal stability, crystalline MMOs offer advantages that are not available in conventional supported catalysts. 

The automotive exhaust abatement market is an ideal application for these mixed metal oxides.  With a continual trend toward reduction in emissions and the rising cost of catalytic metals (Pt, Pd and Rh), the catalyst industry is being squeezed by tightening regulations and the cost of materials required to meet those regulations.

Today our spray pyrolysis process produces catalysts with higher metal dispersions and that translates to a more effective utilization of the precious metals.  We typically see reductions of 50% in the metal required to meet the emission targets mandated for cars in future model years.  Since the SPP manufacturing process is single step, it has the additional benefits of lower manufacturing costs and substantially reduced GHG emissions compared to typical of conventional catalyst manufacturing processes.
